comment_data.body: In pure python mode, you need to use `cython.p_char`

 a ``char*`` value.  You could use the ``atoi()`` function, as defined

comment_data.body: I understand the text in a way that it discuss in context of C language (e.g. it mentions also `stdlib.h` header file.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15,7 +18,17 @@ For example, let's say you need a low-level way to parse a number from
 a ``char*`` value.  You could use the ``atoi()`` function, as defined

comment_data.body:
I don't think it's didactically helpful to use the module's own .pxd file for the declaration. At least not without an elaborate explanation of how it's different from other .pxd files and what it does to your module and its namespace.

You can just name it `strstr.pxd`. That's all it provides, and it (hopefully) suggests naming .pxd files after what they provide.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -103,7 +138,19 @@ You can now make it clear which of the two arguments does what in
 your call, thus avoiding any ambiguities and often making your code
 more readable:
 
-.. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/external/keyword_args_call.pyx

+            :caption: keyword_args_call.py

 your call, thus avoiding any ambiguities and often making your code

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
.. note:: External declarations must be placed in a ``.pxd`` file in Pure
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -83,6 +115,9 @@ This allows the C declaration to be reused in other Cython modules,
 while still providing an automatically generated Python wrapper in
 this specific module.
 
+.. note:: External declarations must be placed in .pxd file in Pure

commit.message: Add pure python mode to Calling C functions tutorial
Improved Pure python doc in Calling C functions tutorial

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Added Pure Python mode to Calling C functions tutorial
